results.title: Physical chemistry of polymers
results.creator_credit: John Friedman, Sol Dworkin and Bell Telephone Laboratories
results.brief_description: Dr. F H Winslow discusses how the physical properties of polymers are affected by molecular size and shape, the packing of molecular clusters as well as the strength of forces between molecules. Includes experiments and demonstrations one of which visually simulates the effects of thermal agitation on rubber molecules.

results.title: Physical aspects of puberty
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adolescent Development”.
Describes, chiefly through animation, the physiological aspects of puberty in girls and boys. Shows that the behaviour problems which seem emotional are often based on the rate of physical growth

results.title: Physcial Education Activities for the Classroom (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A useful and informative film for classroom teachers who do not have daily access to the gymnasium or playing field. It illustrates how the classroom can be effectively used to conduct fitness activities, yoga exercises, modified games, folk and creative dance and many more exciting and challenging activities

results.title: Photosynthesis: The Biochemical process
results.brief_description: From the sun, to green plant, to chloroplasts to grana, this film focuses on the basic life-sustaining process of photosynthesis. The approach is experimental: paper, chromatography, variable lights, spectrophotometric analysis and re-creation of the experiments of Theodore Engelmann, and Melvin Calvin illustrate the physics and chemistry of the photosynthetic process.
results.description: From the sun, to green plant, to chloroplasts to grana, this film focuses on the basic life-sustaining process of photosynthesis. The approach is experimental: paper, chromatography, variable lights, spectrophotometric analysis and re-creation of the experiments of Theodore Engelmann, and Melvin Calvin illustrate the physics and chemistry of the photosynthetic process.

results.title: Photosynthesis
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and TV Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Exciting 3-D computer animations show the dynamic process of photosynthesis at the molecular level. Starting with the historic discoveries of Joseph Priestley, Jan Ingenhousz and Jean Senebier, these six 10 minute episodes examine the absorption of light by plants, and follows the energy pathways to the production of carbohydrates and other organic materials. Programs also develop the Calvin cycle, as it functions in Carbon 3 and Carbon 4 plants, and the remarkable fluid transport system that delivers water and nutrients throughout the plant structure. The programs include: 1. “Seeing the light” 2. “Absorbing the light” 3. “The Light reaction” 4. “The Dark reaction” 5. “C3 and C4 plants” 6. “The Fluid transport system.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and TV Ontario

results.title: Photosynthesis
results.creator_credit: Michael Birch and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explains how green plants transform light energy into food by the process of photosynthesis. Shows the process by which carbon dioxide and water - in the presence of light and chlorophyll - react to produce sugar and release oxygen.

results.creator_credit: Wallace Worsley, Stephen White and Physical Science Study Committee

results.title: Photojournalism
results.creator_credit: Sandra Ostertag, CBS, Coast Community Colleges, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and KOCE-TV (Television station : Huntington Beach, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “The Photographic vision”.
Photojournalist Ross Baughman describes his techniques for obtaining picture stories. Explores the issues of truth, objectivity and ethics in photojournalism.

results.title: Photography: how it works
results.brief_description: Animated film designed to introduce the basics of photography. Explains the relatinship between lens openings and shutter speeds, the way automatic cameras adjust to various light conditions and concepts such as depth of field. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Photoelectric effect
results.creator_credit: Gene Kearney and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description: Presents qualitative demonstrations of photo-electric effect employing the sun and a carbon arc as sources. Also shows an experiment measuring the kinetic energy of the photoelectrons emitted from a potassium surface.
